title.narrative: Emergency Response to people affected by natural and manmade disasters in Kandahar, Nangarhar and Uruzgan.

description.narrative:
Kandahar: From 14 January, 2019 to 18 April, 2019, 252,886 people are affected by natural disasters throughout Afghanistan. A total of 26 provinces out of 34 experienced some kind of natural disaster during the period. Afghanistan is prone to earthquakes, flooding, drought, landslides, and avalanches. During the month of March, 2019 heavy rain in and around Kandahar damaged many houses and inflicting huge loss of livestock and agricultural land. In Kandahar and its surrounding eight districts (Dand, Daman, Arghandab, Zhari, Panjwai, Takhta Pul, Maywand and Spin Boldak) 25 people were killed while 40 others were injured. Moreover, over 4,674 houses were destroyed and/or damaged, thousands of hector of agricultural land was damaged and livestock destroyed. The floods caused many people to leave their place of origin. These IDPs are lacking protection, shelter, access to basic services such as Health and safe drinking water and sanitation, food and livelihood opportunities.
Nangarhar & Uruzgan: From 1 January 2019 to 22 April 2019, 77,954 people fled their homes due to conflict. A total of 22 out of 34 provinces had recorded some level of forced conflict displacement. End of April 2019, the conflict between Taliban and ISIS escalated in Khogyani and Sherzad districts, leading to large scale displacement. As of 30 April 2019, reportedly 56,329 people (8,047 families) were displaced from both districts. According to initial information, 63% (5,073 families) of the displaced people have moved to Surkhrod district, followed by Behsud (1,145 families), while 981 families have settled within Khogyani district (Chamtala settlement and district center). A number of others have moved to Jalalabad city, Kama, Rodat district. People are living in the open, have lost their livelihood, are in need food and lack access to basic services such as healthcare, water and education. Uruzgan is one of the hard to reach provinces in Afghanistan and because of its strategic geographical importance is suffering from continues heavy fighting (as recent as early May) between the Afghan Government and Taliban. The continues fighting since 2016 has destroyed people’s houses, livelihoods and causing many people to flee the violence. Tarinkot, the capital city of Uruzgan, has been receiving thousands of IDPs, urgently need of shelter, NFIs and food.

Long-term objective: To improve the immediate living conditions of 4,900 people (61% children, 39% adults) in 5 districts of Kandahar, Nangarhar and Uruzgan. Short-term objective: To provide life-saving support to 4900 recently displaced conflict and natural disaster affected people.

title.narrative: CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.
